articles.title: A Look at JavaScript's New Set Methods
articles.description: Finding the intersection, union, and difference between sets, among other set-related tasks, is now a piece of cake. Available in Node 22+, Chrome/Edge 122+, Firefox 127+, Safari 17+, and now considered a 'baseline' feature.
articles.author: Brian Smith (MDN)

articles.title: Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2024: What’s New?
articles.description: This week, the Ecma General Assembly approved the latest ECMAScript / JavaScript language spec, officially making it a standard. As with ECMAScript 2023, it’s a small step forward, but Dr. Axel looks at what’s new.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.5
articles.description: One of the most significant TypeScript releases in terms of features in a long time. There’s support for the new Set methods (mentioned above), regex syntax checking, isolated declarations, inferred type predicates, and more. A bumper packed release post.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: 👑 Recreating the Queens Game in Vue
articles.description: Queens is a puzzle game that combines elements of Minesweeper, chess, and Sudoku.
articles.author: Fotis Adamakis

articles.title: Understanding React Compiler
articles.description: The new, experimental tool from the React team automates your performance tuning by rewriting your code — but should you use it, and how does it work under the hood? Tony takes a look.
articles.author: Tony Alicea

articles.title: Uniting Web and Native Apps with 4 Lesser-Known JavaScript APIs
articles.description: Looks at some 'under-the-radar' web features, such as the Screen Orientation API and Contact Picker API, and how they can be used to create user friendly PWAs.
articles.author: Juan Diego Rodríguez

articles.title: Exploring Randomness in JavaScript
articles.description: Specifically, Math.random() versus Crypto.getRandomValues().
articles.author: Ben Nadel

articles.title: Node-RED 4.0 Released
articles.description: Node-RED is a popular ‘low code’ event-driven app development environment that uses Node.js behind the scenes. v4.0 requires Node 18 or up, improves its ‘multiplayer’ support (when multiple users are working on the same system), faster deploys, and other all-round improvements.
articles.author: OpenJS Foundation

articles.title: React-Admin v5
articles.description: A MIT-licensed framework for building React apps on top of REST or GraphQL APIs. You get some added structure and numerous building blocks out of the box. GitHub repo.
articles.author: François Zaninotto

articles.title: wavesurfer.js: Audio Waveform Player Library
articles.description: Get responsive and customizable waveforms that provide a visual impression of audio. There are plugins for working with timelines, recording, rendering spectrograms, and more. Many examples here.
articles.author: katspaugh

articles.title: PixelMatch 6.0: A Fast Pixel-Level Image Comparison Library
articles.description: Give it two images, it’ll highlight the differences. Now distributed as a ES module.
articles.author: Mapbox

articles.title: 📄 PDFSlick: View and Interact with PDFs
articles.description: An interesting PDF viewer for React, Solid, Svelte and other JavaScript apps. Built on top of PDF.js, it uses Zustand to provide a reactive store for loaded documents. Live demos.
articles.author: Vancho Stojkov

articles.description: 📊 Socket's Sarah Gooding has put together a good, easily-skimmed roundup of the State of JS 2023 survey results.
🧊 Someone's created an ASCII 3D renderer in JavaScript. Why? Why not! There's a live demo here.
Playwright 1.45.0 – Microsoft's browser/Web automation library now has a clock API for manipulating time within tests to verify time-related behavior.
Bun v1.1.16 – The fast JavaScript runtime and toolkit.
Astro 4.11, Electron 31.1, PouchDB 9.0, Node.js v20.15.0 (LTS)

articles.title: Morphing Arbitrary Paths in SVG
articles.description: This is a detailed look at morphing SVG paths to create a rather pleasing animation effect. This goes deep on the math to keep things smooth, dealing with sub-paths, and more. There's demos and code here too.
articles.author: Alexandru-Gabriel Ică

articles.title: Inline Conditionals in CSS, Now?
articles.description: Last week we shared news about a recent CSS Working Group resolution to add an if() function to CSS. But that may be some time off from being a working reality — so what can we do in the meantime? Lea takes a look.
articles.author: Lea Verou

articles.title: Uniting Web and Native Apps With 4 Unknown JavaScript APIs
articles.description: A look at some ‘under-the-radar' web features, such as the Screen Orientation API and Device Orientation API, and how they can be used to create user friendly, robust PWAs.
articles.author: Juan Diego Rodríguez

articles.title: The Results from the State of JavaScript 2023 Survey
articles.description: The results of this popular annual JavaScript developer survey are now finally with us. It shares what features devs are actually using, the shifts in library popularity over time, what build tools folks are using, and much more. [→ Via JavaScript Weekly]
articles.author: Devographics

articles.title: ▶  Web Design Engineering with the New CSS
articles.description: A near hour long talk from the latest CSS Day conference exploring how we can use the power of ‘new CSS’ to our advantage along with how to engineer designs that are accessible, resilient, and true to the inherently fluid nature of the web.
articles.author: Matthias Ott

articles.title: A Rant About Frontend Development
articles.description: An opinionated (and expletive peppered) take on the current state of front end development, touching upon CSS strategy, server-side rendering, an over reliance on JavaScript, and more. No surprise to see this one attract plenty of discussion over on Hacker News.
articles.author: Frank M Taylor

articles.title: How to Create Cut-Out Shapes using the clip-path Property
articles.description: A look at how to easily invert an existing shape created using the clip-path CSS property.
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: Pure CSS Circular Text (Without Requiring a Monospace Font)
articles.description: How to create circular text (animated too if you want) with just pure CSS. A nice decorative element.
articles.author: Amit Sheen

articles.title: Using the CSS cap Unit
articles.description: A look at how Ahmad solved a spacing design problem with the CSS cap unit.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: Popovers Work Pretty Nicely as Slide-Out Drawers
articles.description: Another neat use-case for the popover attribute.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: What is 'Mixed Content'?
articles.description: If you’ve ever seen ‘mixed content’ mentioned in the DevTools, now you know what that means.
articles.author: Frederik Braun

articles.title: HTML-Spinner Examples
articles.description: If you want an alternative to spinner images, this might do it for you. The spinner is a custom, self-contained web component that you can treat like any inline HTML tag. No dependencies or frameworks, flexible, and works across all browsers. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Bruce Van Allen

articles.title: Parvus 2.6: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies
articles.description: Ok, it does say not to use overlays on pages but if you really have to, use this! There’s a CodePen example.
articles.author: Benjamin de Oostfrees

articles.title: Sortable: A Sorting Component for Tables, Forms, etc.
articles.description: Built with Next.js, it uses shadcn/ui and Radix UI for the components and dnd-kit for the draggable behavior, which you can try out on a few simple demos.
articles.author: Sadman Sakib

articles.title: KAPLAY: A JavaScript Library for Making Games
articles.description: Dubbed as the “spiritual successor” to the unmaintained Kaboom.js (which it’s also a fork of), this project boasts an easy to use API that you can try out in their online playground.
articles.author: KAPLAY

articles.title: AI CSS Animations: Build CSS Animations with AI
articles.description: Describe your animation with a text prompt (or use your mic) and this tool will generate the keyframes-based CSS for you. Premium access allows you to save and edit existing animations.
articles.author: AI CSS Animations
